text: Dense, New England woods, lit only by the moonlight. The less branches crossing our frame like skeletal hands.

No live organism can continue to exist sanely under conditions of absolute reality, which is why all conscious things - man, child, and beast - must sleep. And dream. The camera moves beyond the trees and branches to REVEAL: A sprawling family home in the woods, all by itself. Larg striking, and brimming with history. Huge windows, brick and iron, with hints of the Gothic in architecture. The longer one stares, the more off-kilter house seems to be. All around, the signs of a RENOVATION IN PROGRESS. Scaffolding, tools, abandoned to the late hour. Someone i working hard on this house. LEGEND: HILL HOUSE. THEN.
Hill House, not sane, stood by itself against its hills, holding darkness within. It had stood so for a hundred years before my family moved in, and it might stand for a hundred more.

We float through the halls. Past the grand staircase. Pas the large, ornate windows. The architecture is old, but t dressing is clearly 1990's. Small HOME IMPROVEMENT projects throughout the house. Fre paint on some elements, absent from others.

Within, walls stood upright, bricks met neatly, floors were firm. Silence lay steadily against the wood and stone of Hill House... We linger on details: CHILDREN’S TOYS, abandoned to the l hour. Patched dry-wall, corners of the bannister in the m of renovation.  2. FAMILY PHOTOS of the CRANES: HUGH (late 30’s), his wife M (late 30's), and the children: STEVEN (11), SHIRLEY (9), THEODORA (7) and the twins, LUKE and NELL (5).
.-- And whatever walked there, walked alone.

INT. STEVEN’S ROOM, HILL HOUSE, THEN - CONTINUOUS A boy's room, with all the expected flourishes of the nineties: a TV, video games. We float toward the boy, asl in his bed, moonlight on his face. He is YOUNG STEVEN (11 We come to rest on Steven’s face, as he’s stirred from sl by a sound... The sound of a CHILD CRYING. He blinks, sitting up.

He steps into the hallway, looking smaller against the sh size of the home. High ceilings, archways. The crying is LOUDER now. He sees his sister YOUNG THEO (7) standing by her door, rubbing her eyes. The crying woke her too.
It’s okay Theo, go back to bed.
Should we wake mom and dad?
I've got it. He moves past her, toward the last door in the hall. He pushes it open.
INT. NELL’S ROOM, HILL HOUSE, THEN - CONTINUOUS He moves into the room. In the soft glow of the night lig he sees YOUNG NELL (5) perched at the foot of her bed. Cr her little tears, clearly afraid.

You okay Nellie? She shakes her head “no.” YOUNG STEVEN (CONT’D) You scared? She shakes her head “yes.” YOUNG STEVEN (CONT’D) That’s okay, I get scared too sometimes. He steps into the room, and looks over to the bed on the other side, where Nell’s twin brother YOUNG LUKE (5) slee soundly, despite his sister's cries. YOUNG STEVEN (CONT’D) Luke sleeps through anything, huh? What was it?
(beat) The bent-neck lady.

Oh, her again. They turn. Standing in the doorway is YOUNG HUGH CRANE. I his pajamas, eyes tired - but still managing a gentle smi YOUNG HUGH (CONT’D) Where was she? Nell POINTS to the foot of the bed, almost where her brot is standing. Hugh smiles, stepping into the room. YOUNG HUGH (CONT’D) Oh boy, let’s take a look. He moves to the spot. YOUNG HUGH (CONT’D) Here, huh? She nods.  YOUNG HUGH (CONT’D) Your big brother must have scared her away. Big brothers are good like that.
What if she’s hiding?

Well let’s make sure she isn’t. Where could she go? Nell’s eyes go to the foot of the bed. Hugh follows her g and crouches to look underneath the bed. YOUNG HUGH (CONT’D) Anyone under here? You better come out, or you’re in trouble. (beat) Hmmm. Not there... He looks up at Nell, who points toward the closet.

Ah. Steven steps aside, watching as his dad goes through the motions for Nell. He smiles, watching close. Learning how Hugh opens the closet door, moving the clothes to the sid YOUNG HUGH (CONT’D) You better come out, bent-neck lady. Stop scaring Nellie. (beat) Nope, she’s long gone. Nell relaxes a little. YOUNG HUGH (CONT’D) And now, everybody can go back to bed. Steven heads for the door, turning to watch his father tu Nell back into bed. YOUNG HUGH (CONT’D) There we go. Do you remember what we talked about before? About our dreams?
They can spill.
That's right. Just like a cup of water spills sometimes. And a kid’s dreams are special, they’re like - At the door, Steven smiles. He remembers this part...
(very softly) An ocean.
An ocean.

That's right. Sometimes the big dreams can spill out. (turns ) Back to bed, Stevie. Steve smiles, and walks away. Hugh turns back to Nell. YOUNG HUGH (CONT’D) I know the bent-neck lady is scary, but that’s all she is. Just a little spill. You know that, right Nellie? She stares at him. She nods.
How long do we have to live here, daddy?
Well, I’ve got to finish fixing the house. And then, somebody has to buy it.
And then we can go?
(smiles, feels bad) Yep, then we can go. Just like the last house. A little relieved. YOUNG HUGH (CONT’D) I love you sweetie. Sweet dreams.

Hugh gently CLOSES Nell’s door. Smiles to himself. He sta down the hall, stopping at another door. Hand-drawn lette reading SHIRLEY, clearly decorated by a little girl. Behind him, we can see NELL’S DOOR, CLOSED, in the BG. From inside, he hears A SOFT VOICE SPEAKING. He pushes th door open. The soft light falls on YOUNG SHIRLEY (9), asl in her bed. Her eyes are closed, but she’s mumbling.
(softly) Dancing in the red room. Don’t step so loud.
(smiling) You're dreaming, Shirl.
The pandas aren’t dreaming.
Pandas, huh?
(trailing off) Pandas don’t eat macaroni...

Noted. He closes Shirley’s door. He’s about to walk away, but tu to see - NELL’S DOOR IS OPEN AGAIN. Odd, he just closed it... He walks back, looking inside. Nell is lying motionless i bed, on her side. She hasn’t moved since he last saw her. Hugh frowns, and gently closes the door once again. He walks away, leaving the upstairs hallway empty and dar We linger for a few extra moments, scrutinizing those shadows. Wondering what they’re hiding...
Hugh CRAWLS back into bed. His wife MARY (30's) stirs.
Everyone alive?
Nellie had a nightmare and Shirley's sleep-talking again.
Anything good?
Pandas don’t like macaroni, Mary. Mary smiles as Hugh kisses her, and settles back into sle Then, a SOUND. Like a GROANING, muffled. From within the walls. Mary’s eyes open.
Again?
You're kidding. He sits up, sighing.
I thought you replaced the pipes -
Gotta be something else, then. Or the guy fucked it up. Another GROAN from the walls. YOUNG HUGH (CONT’D) Fix one problem, find five more. This house is a contractor’s dream.
Then how come they keep quitting? They listen. All is quiet again.
(beat) Nellie’s ready to go.
She's not alone. I miss the city.
This flips how I think it will, I’1ll buy you a penthouse off the park.
With a doorman. She settles back onto her side to sleep.
(chuckles ) Pandas don’t like macaroni. He settles back into his pillow, closing his eyes.

INT. NELL’S ROOM, HILL HOUSE, THEN - CONTINUOUS Nell lays in her bed. She hugs her plush bear to her ches She rolls upright, looking at the spot by the foot of her again. There’s nothing there... though we note the DOOR IS OPEN again. Nell rolls onto her side. Facing her brother's bed. He’s still sound asleep.

Luke? He SNORTS a little in his sleep, and rolls onto his side, away from her. She frowns. She stares at the NIGHT LIGHT, plugged into the wall. It casts WARM COLORS and SHAPES on the wall above it. She fi her attention there. Her eyelids getting heavy... She closes her eyes. We watch her try to sleep for a few moments. And then... Something SHIFTS in the frame behind her. OUT OF FOCUS, I THE DARK, it’s been there this whole time but we’re only
The silhouette of a WOMAN. NECK BENT AT A HORRIBLE ANGLE.
OVERHEAD CU: A smart phone voice recording ap. A finger m into frame, and hits “record.” Legend: SACRAMENTO. NOW.

Carl was driving on Rural 86 during the storm. Do you remember that storm? Course not, you were in LA. It was a bad one. Cats and dogs, worst I’ve seen in ten years. REVEAL MRS. WALKER (50's), seated on her sofa. The sunlig pouring in through the windows. She looks TIRED, bags und her eyes. Absently holding a cup of tea in her hands. MRS. WALKER (CONT’D) He was out there in the boons and he lost control of the car. He went over the guardrail, down a ravine. The car flipped over and you couldn’t see it from the road, especially with the rain. Couldn't even see the lights. Reveal STEVEN CRANE (now grown up, in his mid 30's, a pat expression on his handsome face.) In front of him, his ph records her story. MRS. WALKER (CONT’D) Took me an hour to figure he was late. Almost three hours for someone to start looking for him. And I kept thinking maybe he just stopped off, waited out the weather. She sips her tea. Steven watches, patient. MRS. WALKER (CONT’D) He was, um... he was hanging there, that whole time. Hours. Upside down, tangled up in his seat belt. They said he could reach the horn, but he couldn’t hold it long because - see, his arm was broken. (beat) And that’s how he died. Upside down, pressing on that horn whenever he could stand to. Steven nods, scribbling a NOTE in his notebook.  She leans 10.
So when did it start?

The night after he died. It started with drops of water. I’d be asleep, in our bed, and I'd be woken up because I'd feel... rain, I guess. Raindrops, falling onto my face. I'd wake up, there’d be nothing there. But my face would be a little wet, and my pillow. forward. MRS. WALKER (CONT’D) It got worse. I’d hear a car horn. Short bursts. Distant, I think, but close enough to wake me and then, finally - this was right after the funeral itself, the night after he was buried, you see — Her voice quiets to almost a whisper. She makes MRS. WALKER (CONT’D) I felt the water. On my cheeks, and I heard the horn, and I looked up at the ceiling and... there he was. Hanging there, upside down. eye contact with Steven, shaking her head. MRS. WALKER (CONT’D) I could see the water dripping off his hair, his face was a deep purple, like the blood had all just - pooled - in his cheeks. (beat) It’s funny, you think you'd scream when you see something like that, but you don’t. You just stare. You just stare at it like an idiot, like your brain just... tripped. She swallows. This is hard for her to talk about. MRS. WALKER (CONT’D) So it was dripping off him, the rain and blood too, and he was just staring at me and then his mouth dropped open. But instead of a scream it was - a car horn. Coming out of his mouth. So loud. (MORE )

MRS. WALKER (CONT’D) So loud I fell off the bed. Then I screamed. I screamed because I hit the floor and it startled me, and it was like I only just remembered - “oh, right. I can scream. I should probably scream.” Steven nods, smiling gently. MRS. WALKER (CONT’D) So I screamed all right, and then I ran. Tripped in the hall and looked back and he was gone, and I laid there and I cried and that was... that was the last time I’ve slept in that room. Steven nods. Waits, but it seems her tale is over. He rea forward, and TURNS OFF THE RECORDER.
That’s a very interesting story, Mrs. Walker.
Irene.
Irene. This is what I’d like to do. I'd like to look around your house, and I’d like to set up some equipment. I’d also like to sleep in that room tonight.
Goodness -
I'll be fine. I can’t promise that I‘1l include your story in my book -
Of course -
But it’s possible. And I thank you for sharing it with me.
Well... thank you. For listening.

Steven moves through the house, taking it in. Taking a mo to look at the PHOTOGRAPHS of Mrs. Walker with her husban CARL (60's). Happy photographs, of a normal couple in the golden years. He pauses at one showing Carl by a NEW CAR. Probably the he died in. Steven notes it, and moves toward the bookcas glancing at what’s on the shelves -— HE STOPS. We see one of the titles that has caught his eye: THE HAUNTING OF DANVERS. BY STEVEN CRANE. Next to it, more books. Similar fonts to the titles. THE HAUNTING OF ARLINGTON CEMETERY. BY STEVEN CRANE. THE HAUNTING OF ALCATRAZ. BY STEVEN CRANE. He sighs, not surprised to see the first book, the thicke book: THE HAUNTING OF HILL HOUSE. BY STEVEN CRANE. He reaches out, picking it up. On the cover is a photogra of HILL HOUSE, as we saw it in the beginning. He turns it over, and on the back - WE SEE THE FAMILY PICTURE from 1992, the faces now famili to us. Young Hugh, Mary, Young Steven, and his brothers a sisters...

I’m sorry, I should have told you. I’m a fan. He frowns, looking up. There are at least another EIGHT BOOKS, “THE HAUNTING OF...” series. All written by him. MRS. WALKER (CONT’D) (off the one in his hand) That's my favorite, the first one. “Silence lay steadily against the wood and stone of Hill House, and whatever walked there, walked alone.” (beat) I can’t imagine what it was like... growing up there. The most famous haunted house in America -  He stuffs 13.
In fairness, it wasn’t famous when we moved in.
I remember seeing your dad on TV, during the trial. I always wondered how he kept it together, with all the media, the tabloids -
Well he didn’t exactly hide from the media. (beat) It was a long time ago. the book back onto the shelf.
And besides, you’ve got me beat.
What do you mean?
I mean if you actually saw your husband hanging upside down over your bed, you’ve seen more than I ever have. (beat) I’ve never seen a ghost.
But your books -—
Not at Arlington, Danvers, Alcatraz, the Queen Mary, or in Williamsburg. And not in Hill House.
Oh. The way you write, I assumed -
Other people’s stories. People like you, Irene. I give them the right voice, is all. Mrs. Walker is a little disappointed.
Well I hope tonight is a game changer for you.  14.
How so?
Maybe my Carl can finally give you a story of your own. You were one of his favorite writers, so Maybe... that’s the reason. For all of this. She smiles at him, hopeful. He feels sorry for her.
You know, I can tell you one thing about Hill House that isn’t in the book.
(lights up) Yes, please!
All those years, trying to understand what happened in that house, you know what I never found? (beat) A reason.

(changing the subject) How are your brothers and sisters? I’ve wondered, since the book. How are they doing these days? His PHONE RINGS in his pocket. Saved by the bell. He turn fishing it out. The call is from NELL. It rings for a beat... and he DECLINES THE CALL. MRS. WALKER (CONT’D) You know who I wish would write a book? Your dad. I’d love to hear what he says about that night...
(beat) You and me both. He steps away, looking further into the house.

We watch as the outgoing call to STEVEN ends. Reveal NELL (mid 20's now), looking down at the phone in her hand. The hotel room looks CHEAP, the curtains are DRAWN tight, keeping light out of the room. Nell herself is ON EDGE. Pale, disheveled. Unkempt... and clearly FRIGHTENED. She shakes her head, frustrated - And dials another number: SHIRLEY.
A humble, stately independent funeral home. The sign out front reads HARRIS FAMILY FUNERAL HOME. Legend: MASSACHUSETTS.

A hand holds a phone. The incoming caller is NELL. A mome and then the call is DECLINED. REVEAL SHIRLEY (early 30’s now, kind and genuine.) Sittin a chair, across from a GRIEVING FAMILY. It’s a funeral INTAKE. Her husband RYAN (30's) sits beside her.
I’m sorry. So are you saying you'd prefer not to do a viewing?
No, we want to, it’s not that.
It’s part of your mother’s pre- need, so it’s already taken care of.
And we want to. It’s Max, I think he’s just a little... Shirley turns to MAX (8 years old), who is COLORING by th end table, near the CASKET CATALOGS.  16.
A little nervous about it?
I’d say “adamantly opposed.” In the nearby OFFICE, the LAND LINE rings. Shirley glance Ryan, and he stands to answer.
I'm sorry, excuse me a moment. Shirley smiles, getting up from her chair. She crouches n to little Max.
Hi Max. I’m Shirley. He looks up at her, smiling shyly.
I know this might be a little weird for you, but I promise this is all normal. There’s nothing to be scared of, not a single thing.
(in background) Harris funeral home... she’s with clients, can I have her call you back? He looks back to his drawing.

The reason mommy and daddy are here is that it’s important to say goodbye to Grandma. A viewing is just a way to do that, to see her one last time and tell her you love her. Ryan smiles at Max’s parents. His wife is good at this, a he knows it. Loves her for it.
I don’t need to say goodbye.
A lot of people feel that way at first, but they feel much better when they do.

That’s what mommy said but she was wrong. Grammy keeps sitting on my bed at night and touching my hair. She doesn’t say anything. She doesn’t talk, even if I yell at her. She just stares at me. And her eyes must hurt.
Why?
Because she doesn’t blink. Shirley frowns. INT. HARRIS FUNERAL HOME, FOYER —- LATER 17.
Shirley and Ryan stand with the parents, looking out the front door where Max plays with a toy on the steps.
We see things like this from time to time. He’s what, eight?
That’s right.

He’s still a little too young to really understand death. Kids fall back on memories to help them process it. Whatever their strongest memory is, or their most recent, they’1l pull it up. Replay it. Imagine them doing the things they did in life. The parents exchange glances, unsure.
He'll be fine. You’1ll find the funeral helps. They nod.
Thank you. (beat) (MORE )

I don’t mean to embarrass you, but my wife and I were talking, and we wanted to ask... 18. Shirley forces a smile. She already knows the question. GRIEVING FATHER (CONT’D) You're... Shirley Crane, right?
(beat, smiles) It’s Harris now. She reaches out, taking Ryan’s hand.
I thought so.
But I told her she was probably - makes sense, I guess. Your career choice. (realizes) I’m sorry, I don’t mean offense.
I’m used to it. We’ll talk tomorrow. They watch them head out the doors, into the sun. his arm around his wife.
Who was on the phone?
Your sister. Ryan puts
INT. HARRIS FUNERAL HOME, SHIRLEY’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LATE Shirley sits at her desk, checking voicemail on her cell.

It’s Nell - I need you to call me. It’s hard to explain. Everything's so dark and it’s hard to understand it but... (long beat) It’s about Luke. Just call me.  19. Shirley sighs. She dials Nell back, waiting. It rings. An rings. And rings. And then goes to voice mail. She sighs. Ryan enters, carrying a LARGE FRAME and a hammer.
It’s here! Shirley looks up. He holds up the photograph - it’s of Shirley and Ryan, and THEIR TWO CHILDREN (eight and six), HARRIS FAMILY FUNERAL HOME sign behind them.
That’s great. Ryan goes to the wall, pulling down an older, smaller pho this one without the family.

I think it sends the right message. I sent it to Billy, he’1ll update the website, and I think it could work great for print, too. If people still read papers, that is. He starts HAMMERING a new nail into the wall. Shirley watches, the BANGS of the hammer jarring her -

Young Shirley moves through the house. Around her, we hea LOUD BANGS. LOUDER AS SHE APPROACHES... She rounds the corner just in time to see Young Hugh taki aim with a sledgehammer. He’s targeting a wall, already stripped and opened in sev places. He swings, THE LOUD BANG as the hammer connects. It punch BIG HOLE, and a BURST of dust BLOWS OUT at Hugh’s face. H COUGHS, stumbling back. Laughing a little.
You okay daddy?
Yeah sweetie, just taking out this wall. (wiping dust from his face) (MORE )
House isn’t too happy about it, I guess.
You're too loud.

Sorry honey. This is gonna be great, you'll be able to see right into the dining room. A little counter here, see? (remembers ) Hey. I found something for you. He reaches into his pockets, and pulls out AN OLD METAL K Shirley's face LIGHTS UP.

location: HILL HOUSE, TOP OF THE STAIRCASE, THEN

text: Young Shirley heads up the stairs. Just beyond the landin Mary stands in the hall, looking confused.
Shirl, come here a sec. Shirley has somewhere else she wants to be.
But Nellie and I are -
Just for a second. She heads toward her mother.
Stand here... is it cold? Do you feel cold?
(stands ) Yeah. Mary takes two steps to her right.
Not here though. Shirley follows suit.  21.
Nope.
(stepping back) But here... you feel that? Shirley shivers, nodding.
No vent, no windows - but there’s a draft, right?
Maybe Daddy’s making more holes. Can I go play now?
(lost in thought) The hell is that coming from? Shirley takes that as a “yes,” and bounds down the hall, toward the next set of stairs.
Shirley steps into a LARGE ROOM off the attic. Young Nell already there, playing on the floor in front of a - LARGE RED DOOR. Nell GIGGLES, on her hands and knees, eyes close to the d
I got it!
(eager) Open it! Shirley rushes to the red door, the key in her hand.
Daddy says this is a master key. It’s supposed to open any of the doors in the house -
What do you think is in there? Shirley pushes the key into the lock.  22. YOUNG NELL (CONT’D) What if it’s a cotton candy machine?
(working the key) That'd be something.
Or a pony.
Not a pony. This isn’t working.
You don’t know that, it could be a pony. Something was moving, I saw the shadow under the door.

Daddy said this door’s been locked for years and years and years, so if there’s a pony in there, it’s dead. Nell’s face falls into a horrified shock. Shirley jiggles key, but no luck. The door isn’t opening. YOUNG SHIRLEY (CONT’D) This one doesn’t work either.
(pouting) Where’s the freakin’ key!
(chuckling) Don’t say that word.
You say it. They sit back, staring at the red door. YOUNG NELL (CONT’D) The keys never work. Can’t he just use that big hammer?
He says he’s gonna finish downstairs before he starts up here. (beat) (MORE )
We'll find the key. I wanna see what’s in there too.
If it’s candy, I’ll share it with you fifty and fifty. Shirley smiles at her, brushing the hair from her face.

Come on. Let’s see if daddy has any more keys. They SCAMPER out of the room. The camera LINGERS on the r door. It may just be our imagination... But we swear we see A SHADOW MOVE silently underneath it.
Daddy! We need more keys, it’s an emergency!
Steven holds the phone to his ear as he hooks up an INFRA CAMERA, pointed up to the ceiling above the bed.

(distracted) I know you don’t need me to tell you this, but literally everything is an emergency with Nell. He hits a button on his LAPTOP, and we see the CAMERA FEE the screen. He tests it, recording a few seconds.
Shirley holds the phone to her ear. Behind her, the new picture is displayed prominently.
I know, but she sounded rough.
Shirl -
Rougher than usual. She said it was about Luke.  24.
So call Luke. He leans over the laptop. A few more KEYSTROKES and the footage is logged.
I did. Someone else answered.
So he sold his phone, or traded it, which means he’s using again, which means we stay out of it. I can’t deal with this right now, I’m working.
(with an edge) Yeah? You working? Steven shakes his head. There’s something here, we can al sense the She hangs fight they’re not having, underneath their words...
That's right, Shirley. Something else you want to add?

(beat) Fine. I’1l just handle it, shall I? That's why everybody dumps their shit on me, isn’t it Steve. I’m the oldest, it’s my job. Oh wait - that’s you. up. Steven puts the phone down, shakes it off. Takes a breath, and goes back to setting up his equipment He turns, clutching She hands He turns,
Tea? smiling. Mrs. Walker stands in the doorway, a mug.
Sure, thank you. it over. He takes a sip, nodding his gratitude.
So does this stuff... you know. Capture the supernatural? smiling a little.  25.
Don’t believe in that word.
(confused) Oh...
(smiles) I’m just talking about the word itself; “supernatural.” There’s “natural” phenomena that we understand, and then there’s “natural” phenomena that we don’t. He adjust the camera.

Primitive humans used to die of fright during an eclipse. They had no idea what it was. The eye of an angry god, an evil spirit - nothing supernatural about it, though. Once we understood it, well... it was just “natural.” He sips his tea, sitting on the bed.
I prefer “preternatural.” Natural phenomena that we don’t quite understand yet.
(beat) So will it capture that? The preternatural?
This just captures infrared light. (beat, smiles) But you never know.
Steven has the phone to his ear as he opens the trunk of car. A BEEP as it goes to voice mail.
It’s Steve. Missed your call. Been a minute, hasn’t it. (MORE )
Listen, I’m working but if it’s actually an emer - He closes his eyes, realizing he needs to change his tone

I‘1l be around tomorrow if you still need to chat. I... I hope you're well, Nellie. I mean that. Steven shuts his trunk, throwing his overnight bag over h shoulder. He looks up at the unassuming house he’1l be spending the night in. He leans against the trunk, pulling a cigarette from his pocket. He lights it, drawing deep. Takes a few moments, we can tell something is nagging him. Another drag...
Goddammit. He lifts up his phone. In his contacts, we see: SACRED HEART SHELTER. A number already programmed. He dia
Hey, it’s Steve Crane... yep, and how are you? I wanted to see if Luke’s been staying there lately.

The club is THUMPING. Colored lights, loud music, lots of young people dancing the night away. Close on a MARTINI being set on the bar. A WOMAN’S HAND reaches into frame, wearing a thin DESIGNE GLOVE. She picks up the drink, and lifts it to her lips. She’s THEO (late 20’s now, dark mascara. Effortlessly sex but intentionally unapproachable.) She smiles at the bartender, taking a healthy sip of the drink. She turns her back to the bar, leaning on her elbows. Loo out at the dance floor. Her wandering eyes (and her tight clothes) tell us she’s on the prowl. Across the way, a HANDSOME GUY gives her a smile. Theo ro her eyes, sips her drink. Not interested.  27. Then, someone catches her eye... TRISH (20's, very pretty), leaning against the bar. Theo watches, interested. Slowly TAKES OFF ONE OF HER GLOVES. Trish can feel someone staring at her, and looks. Theo’s staring right at her, a smile on her face. Trish looks aw playing it cool. After a few moments, she turns back to where Theo was leaning. Theo is gone.
Hi. She turns. Theo’s just a few inches away, having closed t distance undetected.
Theodora. Trish smiles.
Trish.

Theo and Trish DANCE. The music blasts, the lights dance across them. Theo is aggressive, confident. Pulling Trish close, lips inches from hers as they writhe together. The dance is very sexual, Trish giving into it as she ARC HER BACK, throwing her head back -

INT. THEO’S BEDROOM - LATER THAT NIGHT - Trish’s head is thrown back, her back arched above the mattress — And she COLLAPSES, EXHALING. Smiling wide, her hair and f glistening with sweat. Seconds later Theo appears from below frame, still wearin tank top, flopping next to her. They catch their breath.
(out of breath) Jesus, where did you come from?  28. Theo looks up at the ceiling, satisfied. Smiles, but we c tell she doesn’t feel much like talking.
How did you do that?! It was like you knew exactly what I -
Haven't been with a lot of girls, have you.
No, that’s not it, it’s just - Theo rolls over. Sits up, reaching over to the night stan Finds what she’s looking for: A joint. She lights it. Trish rolls over, propping herself up.
So what’s your story?
What do you mean?
I mean, who are you? What do you do? Where are you from? Theo takes a drag off the joint. Smiles at her.

I’m here for grad school. Sociology. The program is brutal but I love Boston, it’s such a great town. Do you venture into the city much or stay out here in the ‘burbs? Theo starts PUTTING HER GLOVES back on.
(off the gloves) What’s that about?
I'm kind of a Germaphobe.
(beat) That’s okay, none taken.  29. Theo turns, resting her gloved hand on Trish’s thigh.
That was good.
(leaning closer) Damn right.
I’ve got to work. Early.
Oh. Oh! Okay. She sits up, a little confused. Watching as Theo pulls he jeans back on.
Okay.

INT. THEO’S BEDROOM, FRONT DOOR —- MOMENTS LATER We realize Theo’s apartment is a STUDIO. The bedroom we w just in is actually most of the room. A small kitchenette bathroom. It’s more of a GUEST HOUSE. Theo OPENS the door to let Trish out.
Was it something I did?
Nope. Just not much more to say, we did what we came here to do, yeah?
(disappointed) Okay then. Theo lets her out, and then walks over to the fridge. Ope it up, and takes out TWO BEERS.

Shirley is sitting on the front porch, looking out at the stars over the trees. She hears footsteps coming from aro the side of the house, and looks over to see -  30. TRISH, walking away from THE GUEST HOUSE. Heading up the driveway, toward her car. She stops as she sees Shirley watching her. Shirley waves, casual. Trish waves back, and gets in the Shirley smiles a little, and looks back just in time to s Theo emerge from the front door of the guest house, beers hand. Heading her way.
(holding out the beer) Figured you could use one. Theo sits next to her sister, watching as the car pulls a
New friend? Theo just sips her beer.
She gonna come back?
Oh, no. Sweet enough, but she’s got a pile of issues. Dependency, abandonment issues, so much confusion... (beat) She was a good kisser though.
You know what amazes me? It’s always one date. One date, and you think you know everybody's life story. One night, and they’re codependent. Mommy issues. Emotionally abusive.
They are.
Those aren't things you glean off someone in a few hours, Theo. You’ve got to actually get to know them! People are tough, they take time to show you their true colors.
Not necessarily.  31.
Yeah? How old were you when you came out? Twenty five? Because we didn’t have a clue. None of us. And we've known you your whole life. Theo shrugs it off.
Once there’s a deal breaker, I don’t waste their time. Or mine. I think that’s kinder.
You're like a guy! You’re worse than a guy. You're like a frat guy. When I said you could live here, I wasn’t expecting the pussy parade. Theo chuckles, swigs her beer.
So what's bugging you?
How did you know something was bugging me? (Theo waits) Nell called me today.
So?
She sounded bad.
Because it sucks to be Nell.
She call you?
Nope, she knows better. Haven’t talked to her in three months -
Theo -
If she apologizes, maybe - maybe - we can talk. But until she does, forget it. (MORE )
(beat) What’s wrong with her?
I don’t know.
One foot in crazy and the other on a banana peel. Her whole life. That's just Nell, the worst thing you can do is let yourself feel responsible for her state of mind.
She said it was about Luke. I don’t know, something about it scared me. Theo nods, taking another pull off the beer.
He’1ll show up. When he needs money.
I just keep thinking, what if he doesn’t... or if he does, it’s the last time I’1l ever see him -
I feel that way every time I see him.
You ladies okay? They turn as Ryan steps onto the porch.
Hey sweetie. Yeah, we're okay. Theo finishes her beer.
The beer has gone and so must I. They stand.
Thanks for the company. She hands Theo her beer, which is still HALF FULL. Theo t a sip as Shirley steps inside.  33.
(smiling) And how're you doing? Theo turns her attention to Ryan. Not sure why he’s lingering.
I’m pretty nifty, Ryan. How are you?
I’m good. Theo waits.
Really good. Your sister and I are talking about shutting the business down for a week, maybe getting out of town.
Scandalous.
Not sure if it’s happening yet, just a heads up. She finishes the beer, putting the bottle down.

Well keep me posted, handsome. She turns, walking away. Ryan picks up the bottle, and go to head back inside... LINGERING for just a moment in the doorway. Watching Theo walk away, in those tight jeans...
(without looking back) Good night Ryan. Startled, Ryan pulls the door open.
Good night!

EXT. HUGH’S HOUSE - NIGHT A small, humble house, nestled in the suburbs. Palm trees abound. Legend: FLORIDA INT. HUGH’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS HUGH CRANE (in his 60’s now) is asleep in his bed. Silenc and darkness in the room... We sense the mattress DEPRESS next to him, as though some just climbed into bed with him. Hugh’s eyes SLOWLY OPEN. He waits. Nothing. After a few long seconds... A WOMAN’S ARM SILENTLY REACHES AROUND HIM. Spooning him. Pulling herself up against his back. HUGH DOESN’T MOVE. Just lays there, eyes open. Not making a sound. Her arm hangs around him, and finally GOES LIMP, as if sh just GONE TO SLEEP. VERY slowly, Hugh looks down at the hand dangling in fron him. He swallows. Holds his breath. VERY SLOWLY... so as not to wake her... he begins to ROLL OVER, TURNING TO GET A LOOK AT HER FACE... Slowly he turns, careful to be as SILENT AS POSSIBLE. As he passes the halfway point, almost to the point he co just begin to see her face -

head_text.subj: DIRECTLY IN HIS FACE, A HIGH, SHRILL SCREECH -

text: HUGH’S EYES FLY OPEN. HE BOLTS UPRIGHT IN BED. HE’S ALONE... NO ONE ELSE IS THE The SHRILL SCREECH is just his RINGING PHONE.  35. He catches his breath, letting the nightmare recede. The phone keeps ringing, and he finally lifts it off the nigh stand. IT’S NELL. He answers the phone, shaken, slowly waking up.
Nell?
Daddy...
Honey? You okay? What time is it? He starts to shuffle in the bed, getting comfortable, settling back down.
(beat) Do you remember the bent-neck lady? HUGH SITS UP IN BED. Staring ahead, very still now. The color has DRAINED FROM FACE. He takes this VERY SERIOUSLY.
(quietly) Yes.
She's back. Hugh swallows. Catches his breath.
Okay. Okay. (beat) Where are you?
INT. NELL’S CAR - INTERCUT Nell is behind the wheel of her car. The engine isn’t running. It is VERY DARK outside, she’s surrounded by OVERGROWN TREES. No street lights AT ALL.
I’m at home. In bed.  36. Like she’s parked in the MIDDLE OF THE WOODS.
INT. HUGH’S BEDROOM - INTERCUT Hugh sighs.

Okay, stay there. Listen... I want you to go to Steve and Shaye’s. I can drive to Orlando, get a flight to L.A. in the morning. Steve’s the closest, you go to him, and - (beat) I‘1l meet you there, sweetie. Nell smiles a little. Sadly.
Okay. I love you, daddy. Something about the way she says it doesn’t sit right wit Hugh.
Are you okay? INT. NELL’S CAR - INTERCUT Nell smiles, sadly. Tears fall down her cheeks, but her v doesn’t betray her feelings.

I'm fine. I’m sorry to wake you. Good night, daddy. She hangs up. Takes a deep breath. Looks forward, at something we can’t see, in the darkness beyond the front the car. Then, she GETS OUT OF THE CAR, leaving the DOOR OPEN... a walks into the darkness.

INT. HUGH’S BEDROOM - INTERCUT Hugh stares at the phone in his hand. Looking around his room, taking deep breaths. THIS MAN IS AFRAID. He shakes head, this isn’t possible...  37. Finally, he gets up. Goes to his closet, pulling his bags down. He QUICKLY PACKS HIS THINGS, throwing just what he needs the suitcase. Bag in hand, he PULLS THE BEDROOM DOOR OPEN -
- YOUNG HUGH BURSTS through Young Steven’s door, startlin the boy.
Get up. Stevie, get up.
Dad? What’s —
Get up, we have to get out of here. Right now.
Why? What’s -
Quietly. He pulls Steven up by the arm, moving him toward the door
My shoes -

Shhh. Hugh pokes his head out into the hallway - AND QUICKLY PULLS IT BACK, as though he SAW SOMETHING. Slowly, silently, he PULLS THE DOOR CLOSED. He keeps one hand on the doorknob, and raising a finger t his lips with the other. “Shhhh.” Steven nods, confused. He stares at his father. Hugh is SWEATING, PALE. PANICKED Steven studies him, he doesn’t know why his father is act like this.  38. Then he hears - FOOTSTEPS IN THE HALLWAY. Moving closer and closer. Slow, almost SHAMBLING. Hugh holds the door knob, reaching up to gently PUSH THE BUTTON LOCK. They wait in silence as the footsteps REACH THE DOOR. Nothing for a few seconds... AND THEN THE KNOB STARTS TO TURN. Softly, exploring. Hugh RELEASES HIS GRIP but keeps his hand hovering around door knob, watching it turn softly. They wait, HOLDING THEIR BREATH... And the footsteps BEGIN TO WALK AWAY. Further and further down the hallway they go, until all i silent again. Hugh turns to his son. YOUNG HUGH (CONT’D) (whispering) We're going to run.
Dad, what's happening -
Quiet. He reaches down for the doorknob, and slowly -

head_text.subj: TRYING NOT TO MAKE A SOUND -
TURNS THE KNOB UNTIL THE LOCK DISENGAGES.

text: He takes a breath, and then silently PUSHES THE DOOR OPEN pokes his head into the hall, looking both ways. After a moment, he STARTS BREATHING AGAIN. He turns to Steven. YOUNG HUGH (CONT’D) I’m going to carry you.
What? I can -  39.
Hold on to me, very tight. Keep your eyes closed. No matter what you hear, don’t open them. Do you promise?
Do you promise?

(beat) I promise. Hugh SCOOPS him up, which is tough. He’s not a little kid anymore. Steven awkwardly wraps his arms around his dad’s neck, hooking his legs around his hips. Hugh WINCES from the weight, but manages to support him.
Eyes closed. No matter what. Eyes closed. Steven shakes his head, rests his chin on his father’s shoulder, and CLOSES HIS EYES. YOUNG HUGH (CONT’D) (to himself) Okay. Okay... okay.

He pushes the door open and starts moving FAST down the hallway. WE STAY ON STEVEN’S CLOSED EYES. We hear - HUGH'S FOOTSTEPS, heavy with the weight of both of them. But then, something else — BANGS. CREAKING WOOD. As though the house around him is MOVING AS WELL.

(desperate) Eyes closed!  40. The BANGS GET LOUDER, and then - AN EAR-SHATTERING SCREECH comes from the other end of the hall. A woman SCREAMING, growing in volume and intensity - Just as Hugh is about to round the corner, Steven OPENS H
YOUNG STEVEN'S POV: The hallway, dark, but for just a spl second before we turn the corner we think we see - A WOMAN, AT THE FAR END OF THE HALLWAY -— EITHER IN A NIGHTGOWN OR A LONG DRESS -—
Hugh turns the corner, and we can’t see any more.
Hugh’s feet THUNDER down the stairs, clutching Steven to Sprinting toward the door. Behind them, a HORRIBLE VOICE SHRIEKS:
Hugh barrels toward the front door, WHICH IS ALREADY OPEN Panting, gasping for air, he RUNS OUTSIDE, the boy in his arms.
Hugh SPINS Steven in his arms, putting his FEET ON THE GROUND.

The car! Steven’s eyes are open now, he starts RUNNING next to his father, panicked. Behind them, the front door of Hill House SLAMS SHUT.  41. Steven starts to turn to look, but Hugh PUSHES him forwar YOUNG HUGH (CONT’D) Keep going! As Steven nears the car, he sees -— ALL OF HIS SIBLINGS ARE ALREADY INSIDE. Nell up front. Theo, Shirley, and Luke are all there, in their pajamas, all shouting and panicked. They get to the car and Steven opens the back door, climb in. Hugh races for the driver's seat.
INT. HUGH’S CAR, THEN -—- CONTINUOUS Young Hugh FUMBLES with the keys, trying to get the car started. Around him, the kids shriek.
What’s happening?! What’s happening?!
Daddy!! Daddy?! Nell just SOBS LOUDLY. Hugh IGNORES THEM, TURNING OVER th engine. It ROARS as he floods it with gas. Steven surveys the scene, breathing heavy, and REALIZES -

(realizing) Where’s mom? Steven looks back up at the house as - Hugh FLOORS IT. The tires DIG INTO THE GRAVEL, throwing it up behind the as he swings it onto the drive. The kids SHOUT and CRY, panicked and lost. YOUNG STEVEN (CONT’D) Where’s mom! Dad, where’s mom! Hugh ignores him. Drives as FAST AS HE CAN away from Hill House, while his children scream and cry.  42. Steven turns around in his seat, looking at the house, da against the woods, as it gets smaller in the window. In the GRAND, GOTHIC UPSTAIRS WINDOW he sees -

head_text.subj: THE SILHOUETTE OF A WOMAN, IN A LONG NIGHTGOWN

text: YOUNG STEVEN (CONT’D) Dad! Dad! We can’t leave mom! Where’s mom! Hugh drives, CRYING NOW. YOUNG STEVEN (CONT’D) Dad! Dad! DAD!
Dad... Steven holds his phone to his ear, speaking softly while PACES. The house is dark, all of his equipment is set up running.
Dad, I can’t. INT. HUGH’S CAR - INTERCUT Hugh DRIVES in the dark, pale.
You’re the closest. Your sister needs you.
She’s freaked about Luke. I already called all the shelters and the clinics looking for him, like she wanted -
That’s not -  43.
- and unless he shows up in a morgue, we all know what he’s doing. He’ll pop up in a week or two looking for money, just like every other time -
This isn’t about Luke.
Nell said it was.
It’s about her. Get home, stay with her. Don’t let her out of your sight. I'll meet you there.
Dad, listen, I’m not even - Hugh hangs up.

- living at home right now. He lowers the phone. Sighs. AT THE INFRARED CAMERA: Steven takes a look at the ceilin above the bed. Just grey, nothing unusual. He scribbles a note, checking his watch. AT THE WINDOW: Steven looks out at the street below. They on the corner lot, the empty roads lit by street lights. The roads SHIMMER with the faint rain. He settles into the bed. On his back, still clothed. Look around. Steven’s POV: the ceiling above him. No spirit, just the light fixture. He closes his eyes, going to sleep.
INT. THEO’S BEDROOM - LATER THAT NIGHT The camera slowly moves in on Theo, asleep in her bed. We drift toward the ALARM clock. We see the time, glowing red in the darkness: 3:02 am.
As we watch, it changes to 3:03... And Theo suddenly BURSTS UP IN BED, a startled SCREAM in throat. She GASPS, her hand absently clutching her neck. Eyes wid Like she woke from a nightmare.

INT. HARRIS FUNERAL HOME, SHIRLEY’S ROOM - NIGHT Ryan is STARTLED by a SHORT SCREAM. DISORIENTED, he sits looking around as he gets his bearings - SHIRLEY IS SITTING UPRIGHT IN BED. Gasping, breathing hea Hand over her heart.
(catching her breath) Nellie’s in the Red Room...
Shirl? She blinks at him. Snapping out of it.
Oh... sorry...
What’d you say?
I don’t... what? We can tell she can’t remember. And we notice, though he doesn’t, the clock beside her. 3:03.

WAKING WITH A START, A STRUNG-OUT YOUNG MAN (20's, filthy scrambles to his feet. Under the overpass there are tents blankets - the tiny homeless colony common to the city. He knocks against the trash can, startling others. Starin wildly at the BLANKET he was just asleep on, eyes wide.

Steven’s eyes BURST OPEN. He looks around, catching his breath. Something woke him up... We realize the clock beside him reads 12:03 am. There’s nothing in the room. Steven slowly closes his eye going back to sleep. From high above him, the camera SLOWLY BOOMS DOWN on his until we land in a CLOSE UP... A DROP OF WATER HITS HIS FOREHEAD. He opens his eyes. Looks up at the ceiling... NOTHING OUT OF THE ORDINARY. Just the light fixture, and whole lot of ceiling. He WAITS. WAITS... ANOTHER DRIP. Intrigued, Steven ROLLS OUT OF BED. Stands up. Looks at the ceiling, the light fixture. Waits. Looks down at the pillow on the bed... WAITS... DRIP. A drop of water hits the pillow. Steven STEPS UP ONTO THE BED, looking up at the ceiling. He STRETCHES ON THE TIPS OF HIS TOES, trying to identify source of the water... WAITS... WAITS...

Steven SPINS, almost FALLING off the bed. He turns, looki out the window - And from his height, he can see the TWO CARS in the intersection that just avoided a collision. Another SHORT HONK, and they go off in separate ways.  46. Steven SMILES, catching his breath. STEVEN'S POV: The intersection, dark.
- Steven's POV: The intersection, IN DAYLIGHT.
There was a stop sign there until recently, yes? Steven stands at the window, with Mrs. Walker next to him
.--. I don’t know, I think so.
There’s a pole there, see? But no sign. There is indeed a silver pole sticking up from the ground the intersection... but nothing on it.
Kids take them for their dorm rooms. It’s a moderately trafficked area; a four way stop without a sign is bound to have a few near misses. (beat) You slept better with your husband in bed, right?
Of course.

You're probably just noticing the car horns now because you’re not sleeping as well. Things you used to sleep through. (beat) The water... Steven hops up onto the bed. He reaches up, slowly turnin unscrewing the bolt holding the light fixture.  47.
It was a big storm the night he died, one of the biggest you've seen in a long time.
Yes...
There’s a leak in your roof. And you just didn’t notice the water damage because... He removes the bolt, and PULLS DOWN THE LIGHT FIXTURE. Th where the power cord goes into the ceiling, is a WATER ST

It was covered. It was only drizzling last night, and I even got a few drips. He places the light fixture on the night stand, and waits patiently. Mrs. Walker looks up at the stain, and we can tell... SHE’S EMBARRASSED.
This happens all the time, Mrs. Walker.
And the man I saw hanging from my ceiling? Steven sighs, sitting on the mattress.
The mind... it is a powerful thing, ma’am. Especially the grieving mind.
I know what I saw -
The water, the car horn, you’d be picturing how he died, as much as you wouldn’t want to -
I saw him.  48.
And when you push that stuff down, it comes out at night. You couldn’t help it. She shakes her head. She’1ll buy the rest, but not that. Steven frowns. He speaks softly, gentler.
When I said I’ve never seen a ghost, that’s not exactly true. I’ve seen a lot of ghosts. Just not the way you think. He steps closer, sympathetic.
A ghost can be a lot of things. A memory, a daydream. A secret. Guilt, grief, anger. But in my experience, most times they’re just what we want to see -
He looked so horrible. Why would I want to see my Carl... like that?
Because it’s better than never seeing him again. She looks at him, tears in her eyes.
Most times, a ghost is a wish.

Steven reaches up, taking down the copy of THE HAUNTING O HILL HOUSE from the book shelf. He looks at it, sighs. He sits down on the couch, pen in hand. Opens the book, t the title page, and starts to inscribe. “To Irene... thank you, and Carl, for your support. ‘And whatever walked there... walked alone’. He signs his name with a flourish. Mrs. Walker watches, smiling to herself.
Thank you for doing that. Carl would have loved it.
My pleasure. He finishes signing, and closes the book. Looks at the co and the photograph of his childhood home. As he stares at

INT. STEVEN AND SHAYE’S APARTMENT - EVENING A MANUSCRIPT of THE HAUNTING OF HILL HOUSE is forcefully DROPPED on the table in front of Steven. He’s a few years younger, and living in a modest apartmen He looks up, startled by the loud noise. Shirley stands i front of him... she’s PREGNANT.
The fuck, Steve.
You didn’t like it?
No. I didn’t like it. From the other room, Steven’s wife SHAYE (30's) enters, a little alarmed by the argument.
What’s going on?
My brother just raped the family, is what’s going on.
Hang on.
Look, I get that things haven't exactly been going well with your writing, and when you said you were doing a book about the house I understood that. But this -  50.
I sent you guys the manuscript in case you objected to anything, I didn’t have to do that -
Of course I object! We object, Steven!
Let’s calm down a bit -
You be calm, Shaye, your name’s not in here. He’s not exploiting your worst memories for some sensationalized coffee table book, it’s not your family -
(hurt) Hey! It is my family, I’m a Crane now too -
You weren’t there. (back to Steven) Nell. Luke. Theo. They were just kids, the things they told you in confidence -
I’m clear that they were kids -
You make mom sound fucking crazy -
Oh, mom wasn’t crazy?
And the Dudleys, and dad - this is the worst of the bullshit, worse than dad with the tabloids -
Dad's had every opportunity to set it straight - what am I supposed to write? He said it was haunted, those are his words -
He was a wreck! He just lost his wife -
- and he hasn't said shit about it since then! Does he talk to you, Shirl? Has he told you what happened that night? Because all I’ve got are the tabloid quotes, he refuses to tell us anything else -
He believed it, Steve! This shuts him up.
When he said those things he believed them, in the moment at least, but you... you never did -
Neither did you -
- and now you're digging up all that stuff, so you can make a buck and stop living on credit for a change -
(incredulous) A buck. Shaye steps into the room, toward her husband. Cautious, knows how this goes...
Honey, she’s upset, don’t make it -
You know how much they offered on the advance? A buck... this is a life for us, Shirl. We can get a house. We can move to L.A. I have to start a real life. For my own family -
We’re your family, Steve. (beat) And what you're doing to mom -
Mom was mentally ill. It’s a fact. And damned if the apple didn’t fall too far from -—  52. He STOPS HIMSELF. Too far. Shirley GLARES, the wound obvi
Wow.
(standing, regretful) I’m sorry. That wasn’t -
Wow. He holds his hands up, and we see he truly regrets saying that. Shirley collects herself.
You sent me your book, now you know what I think. You publish this, you know what it costs.
(quietly) No one’s buying the novels, Shirl. I have a chance here, to make a real life -
You know what it costs. She turns, walking away. Shaye moves to Steven, and puts arm around him as they watch Shirley go. Steven looks bac down at the manuscript on the table, the title page -
Steven stares at the book for a moment, and then hands it Mrs. Walker.
I‘1ll write your story. She blinks. Surprised.
It’s a good story, Mrs. Walker. And I researched your house - did you know it was used as a hospice briefly in the sixties?
I didn’t.  53.

And I'd like to talk to you more about your marriage, get some background on Carl. Who he was, who you both were. That’s what matters, really. I’1l need to take some liberties, I always do, but I promise to be respectful. (beat, encouraging) He was a fan. I'll do it in a way he would have really liked. She nods. Steven stands, and begins packing up his equipm
You really didn’t see anything? Steven frowns. He feels for her.
They didn’t see anything.
YOUNG HUGH paces in the attorney’s office. Young Steven watches on.
That’s not the point -
My kids don’t take the stand, Ross. I’ve been clear about that.
I had my eyes closed when we left -
Don’t say anything, Stevie.
No one else can corroborate your story, Hugh!
That’s right.  54.
Look, the jury hears you talk about packing five kids into your car at three in the morning, they’re gonna wonder why they aren’t hearing from those kids! Not a single one -
Right. Not a single one.

The media’s already piling on, if we don’t give them someone else to write about, it’s gonna be more of this - He DROPS TWO TABLOIDS on the table in front of them. Stev sees the headlines: “Crazy Crane Claims Hill House Haunted” “Hugh Crane Trial: Blames Ghosts for Wife’s Death!” Steven looks up at his father. SEEING HIM DIFFERENTLY NOW
We don’t engage.
They got this off your statement! To the police!
I wasn’t thinking clearly that night, we lean on that.
You can’t un-ring a bell -
Fine, they can rip me to pieces. They don’t get to take bites out of the kids.

Okay. We do it your way. It’d just go a long way if I you’d let the press near the house - hell, they’1l pay you! They’d pay to walk the grounds, take some pictures, that money could help cover your defense -  55.
No one goes near the house. The cops have to, but no one else.
Then sell it, you need the money -
No.
Hugh... you’re saying you want to keep the house your wife just died in. Do you know how that looks? Hugh shakes his head. This guy doesn’t get it...
I want the gates and doors locked. I want the only keys. I want to know, every day, that it’s empty. No gardeners, no staff, no grounds keeping. (beat) I want it to sit there and rot.
INT. HUGH’S CAR, THEN - DAY They drive. Young Steven looks up at his father from the passenger seat. Stares at him. Hugh feels the gaze.
I’m sorry you had to hear that.
What happened, dad? Hugh doesn’t answer.

(long beat) It’s going to be okay. I promise you. Steven stares at his father, realizing for the first time that he DOESN'T BELIEVE HIM... CLOSE on Young Steven, looking at the driver. We cut arou to his POV:
INT. STEVEN'S CAR -— DAY STEVEN is driving. We’re now in his car, many years later The passenger seat is EMPTY. He PASSES a sign: LOS ANGELES - 180 miles. A VOICE from his car speakers:
I’m sorry, there’s no Luke Crane at our center. We can contact you if he shows up.

I appreciate that. Thanks! He reaches out, hanging up the call. Drives, frowning. Considers... and then reaches out, hitting the SPEED DIAL button on his console. Selects the first name on the list SHAYE. It rings. After several rings, a woman’s voice picks up.
(long beat) Hello.
Hey. There's a beat between them. She’s waiting for him to spe he’s not sure what to say.
What do you want?
So my sister - there’s something up with Nell, she may show up at the house today.
(beat) At my house?
At the house, yeah.
Why?  57.
My dad told her to, and I didn’t get a chance to tell him what's... She sighs. Steven looks down at the WEDDING RING on his finger, gripping the steering wheel.
I’m sorry, you can just point her to me.
Is that all? He shakes his head. Frustrated. He’s not sure what to say could take this conversation in a few different direction and we sense him trying to pick the one least likely to combust...
Maybe I can come by, and we can talk about this some more? Nothing.

How long does this need to go on, Shaye? You tell me what I have to do, and I'll do it. I mean, I just want to come home - SHE HANGS UP. He sighs. The road rolls forward in front of him... but t traffic is SLOWING.
Great. He slows. Ahead, down the rural highway, it’s BUMPER TO BUMPER. An accident, most likely.
Just great. He sits there, staring at the unmoving car. And at the TR beside the highway... some of the Northern California for between the bigger cities. He stares. Thinks. Remembers...
The view of the woods, through a window. Another time, be that night. Before the escape... Reveal YOUNG STEVEN looking out at the trees... and at th TREE HOUSE near the house. Behind him, MARY PACES.
Luke? Luke! Has anybody seen your brother? Steven smiles, eyes on the tree house.
Steven crosses the yard, heading toward the tree house. H made, clearly with love, the structure itself sits on an ancient tree, cradled by huge branches. Steven climbs the ladder.
Steven POPS UP through the trap door. Nearby, coloring on floor, YOUNG LUKE (5) JUMPS.

Mom's looking for you. Steven starts to climb up. Luke goes back to coloring. YOUNG STEVEN (CONT’D) Trying every closet. Every single one. It never occurs to her you’ll be in your tree house. (beat) The one dad built. For you. Luke giggles. YOUNG STEVEN (CONT’D) Dinner’s ready.
I don’t wanna go in yet, I don’t like it inside.  59.
I hear you. Distant, we hear MARY'S VOICE calling, presumably out the front door.
